repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: No `:checkhealth` entry. Solution: Add `:checkhealth vim.pack`. Design it around validating assumptions about `vim.pack` usage and giving actionable advice to fix possible issues. In particular: - Basic requirements are met: `git` executable, lockfile, and plugin directory are present. - Lockfile has correct shape (json with correct field types) and aligns with plugins on disk (revision and source are as expected). - Plugin directory has proper entries: all directories, in the state that `vim.pack` might leave them. Also notify if there are not active plugins. Those might be lazy loaded (okay) or removed an entry from the config without `vim.pack.del()` (not okay). - Make sure that it passes with brief feedback if it doesn't look like `vim.pack` is being used. --- Resolve #34777. I wasn't sure how thorough the checkhealth is welcome here, so decided to (at least start with) how I'd right them for my plugin. Here are examples of how checkhealth performs:
Not used
Pass
Lockfile missing
Lockfile is not a valid json
Lockfile has not valid types
Lockfile is not aligned with plugins on disk
Info about not active plugins

comment_data.body: We already check these tools in `check_external_tools`. Perhaps this function could be made more generally useful in some way, so it can be reused by individual health modules, which would also benefit plugin authors. ðŸ¤”
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,258 @@
+local M = {}
+
+local health = vim.health
+
+local function get_lockfile_path()
+  return vim.fs.joinpath(vim.fn.stdpath('config'), 'nvim-pack-lock.json')
+end
+
+local function get_plug_dir()
+  return vim.fs.joinpath(vim.fn.stdpath('data'), 'site', 'pack', 'core', 'opt')
+end
+
+local function git_cmd(cmd, cwd)
+  cmd = vim.list_extend({ 'git', '-c', 'gc.auto=0' }, cmd)
+  local env = vim.fn.environ() --- @type table<string,string>
+  env.GIT_DIR, env.GIT_WORK_TREE = nil, nil
+  local sys_opts = { cwd = cwd, text = true, env = env, clear_env = true }
+  local out = vim.system(cmd, sys_opts):wait() --- @type vim.SystemCompleted
+  if out.code ~= 0 then
+    return false, ((out.stderr or ''):gsub('\n+$', ''))
+  end
+  return true, ((out.stdout or ''):gsub('\n+$', ''))
+end
+
+local function check_basics()
+  health.start('vim.pack: basics')
+
+  -- Requirements
+  if vim.fn.executable('git') == 0 then

comment_data.body:
> We already check these tools in `check_external_tools`.

It was added for `vim.pack`, so it looks appropriate to move it here (which this PR does). No strong opinions, though.

If having `git` executable would be needed for something else in core - maybe moving back to general check health might be good. But I'd still find it surprising to have a check for a required external tool *outside* of a dedicated checkhealth section.

comment_data.body: I agree with @glepnir here; I think it's better to keep this check together with the other external tools -- this way, people get the warning even if they don't use `vim.pack` but another plugin manager, which means _they_ don't have to duplicate that check.

comment_data.body:
Pet peeve (out of scope for this PR, of course): The output order of `:checkhealth` is not deterministic; since there can be a lot of text (treesitter, I'm looking at you...), it would be great if
1. the "core" section `vim.health` could always be first
2. "plugin" sections always come after builtin sections.

(Further builtin order TBD.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,258 @@

comment_data.body:
> I think it's better to keep this check together with the other external tools -- this way, people get the warning even if they don't use `vim.pack` but another plugin manager, which means _they_ don't have to duplicate that check.

This doesn't sound right. Here is the reasoning:

- I'd expect `:checkhealth vim.pack` (or any other scope) to be self contained. If moved to previous spot, then `git` executable check will be skipped and users with this problem will get "All good" result.
- The "external tools" part is visible only after pure `:checkhealth`, without arguments. If its built-in parts are intended for plugin authors to rely on, this makes it awkward to suggest "Run `:checkhealth`, see both 'External tools' section of `vim.health` check and `my-plugin` check". Instead "Run `:checkhealth my-plugin` and see results" is much more straightforward.

    Besides, running `:checkhealth` would still show missing `git` executable in `vim.pack` section if located there.

My expectations are:
- Running `:checkhealth <scope>` should always be self-contained. In this case it means having `git` executable check inside `:checkhealth vim.pack`.
- The "External tools" part of `vim.health` check is about tools that 1) are about built-in Nvim functionality; 2) don't fit dedicated scope or are for Neovim development.

So I guess it might make sense to duplicate (not fully move) `git` executable check in `vim.pack` scope, but not having it present in `:checkhealth vim.pack` is really confusing.

comment_data.body: I guess you're right; duplicating is the way to go here.

comment_regular_data.body:
I don't think this works correctly, because it doesnâ€™t seem to considers `version` field.

```

==============================================================================
vim.pack:                                                           1 âš ï¸  1 âŒ

vim.pack: basics ~
- Git: version 2.52.0 (/usr/bin/git)
- Lockfile: /home/matej/.config/nvim/nvim-pack-lock.json
- Plugin directory: /home/matej/.local/share/nvim/site/pack/core/opt
- âœ… OK 

vim.pack: lockfile ~
- âŒ ERROR Plugin "acme.vim" is not at expected revision
  Expected: 4a303347645666654897a2f45c0c8c993cfb68d8
  Actual:   f92ec3b5b39be25c58d7587de992960368dcc8d9
  To synchronize, restart Nvim and run `vim.pack.update({ "acme.vim" }, { offline = true })`

vim.pack: plugin directory ~
- âš ï¸ WARNING Plugin "acme.vim" is not at state which is a result of `vim.pack` operation.
  If it was intentional, make sure you know what you are doing.
  Otherwise, restart Nvim and run `vim.pack.update({ "acme.vim" }, { offline = true })`.
  If nothing is updated, plugin is at correct revision and will be managed as expected
```

The definition is

```lua
    {
        src = 'https://github.com/openSUSE-Python/acme.vim.git',
        version = 'neovim'
    },
```

and truly `neovim` branch is at https://github.com/openSUSE-Python/acme.vim/commit/f92ec3b5b39be25c58d7587de992960368dcc8d9, so it is checked out where it is supposed to be.
https://github.com/xyb3rt/acme.vim/commit/4a303347645666654897a2f45c0c8c993cfb68d8 is the upstream `main` branch.

> I don't think this works correctly, because it doesnâ€™t seem to considers `version` field.

It looks like `:checkhealth vim.pack` is doing its job well here. There is a "WARNING Plugin "acme.vim" is not at state which is a result of `vim.pack` operation. If it was intentional, make sure you know what you are doing.". It means that after plugin was installed on the disk, there was some manual operation to it outside of `vim.pack` commands. Probably a `git checkout main` . This makes plugin on disk be not as what `vim.pack` expects it to be (which is determined by the lockfile). To mitigate this, following the mentioned advice helps.

I've checked with clean install and provided spec. Everything is expected: state is `f92ec3b5b39be25c58d7587de992960368dcc8d9` and `:checkhealth vim.pack` shows all OK. Making manual `git checkout main` inside the plugin's directory indeed shows the same `:checkhealth vim.pack` output. And indeed following the advice of `:lua vim.pack.update({ "acme.vim" }, { offline = true })` makes it update to the state of `neovim` branch.

repo.name: neovim

title: Add `:checkhealth vim.pack`
